intro: Agrostophyllum latilobum, commonly known as the broad-lobed sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of Australia. It belongs to the family Goodeniaceae and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming structure with hairy stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale blue flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It is well adapted to sandy soils and can tolerate drought conditions, making it a hardy species in harsh environments. Its ecological role includes providing habitat and food for native wildlife.
